ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course is a cursory look at land use case law. We didn't get particularly deep into the material, and the course felt a bit scattered. The professoris a wonderful, lovely human being.
This was a great overview of local land use issues and law. I appreciated the discussion of current events in New Haven and neighboring towns.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Professor Shansky is great. A total sweetie.
I enjoyed the projects at the end of the semester--both putting together my own project, and listening to other students' presentations.
I am a nerd and really liked the case readings. Researching the final project was fun, too. I appreciated Marjorie Shansky's enthusiasm, knowledge, and accessibility!

Marjorie is a wonderful instructor! She is extremely knowledgable and passionate about land use law, highly respected in her field, and she's also a lot of fun. I wish that Marjorie taught other classes at Yale, too!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: We needed to cover the material more rigorously.

This is a class at FES, not at the law school. It's not cross-listed with YLS, and as such, there are very few students in the class with prior law experience.That said, Professor Shansky is running the class like a law class--with students volunteering (not being called on!) to discuss the cases.Without prior legal experience on the part of the students, this is often an exercise in frustration; legal cases can be hard to parse, and I often felt that many in our class struggled with understanding the cases, much less being able to discuss them clearly. Thus, class time often got extremely frustrating, with many students not paying as much attention as they could have been (myself included).I would really like to see Professor Shansky taking a more active role in teaching--in other words, to run the class more like an FES class, and less like a traditional legal class. I think this would have helped all of us gain a better understanding of the material. In this context, learning (a little bit about) how a normal legal class works is significantly less valuable than learning the material as well as we can.
We were always behind in the readings -- maybe require all of them, but then only pick the 2 or 3 most relevant for presentation during class time?

I imagine this varies greatly year to year, but our class didn't seem particularly engaged in relevant case discussion / were reluctant to participate; not sure that people actually did the reading. I think you really get out of this course what you put into it.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It fit well as an overview to land use law issues faced by developers and those interested in natural resources. It was also interesting to learn more about New Haven and CT.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to see if land use law has a role in advocacy in the food system. Also, I wanted to learn how to read case law.
I'm interested in all aspects of land conservation.
Wanted to understand local law issues, zoning, etc.
Interesting and relevant topic.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Meh, kind of. I know where to look now. I would have liked to learn more about land use law. The course did help me understand how to read case law, and IRAC out cases in a legible way.
Mostly--I wish we could have focused less on cases and more on general principles.
Yes
Yes, absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Pick a project early. Learn from the project and use Professor Shansky's expertise. Dont expect much from the case law.
It teaches the basics of Land Use Law--which is very important if you're planning on working in either city planning or land conservation. However, be prepared to read a lot of cases.
Do the reading in a structured way -- take notes on a computer, answering the same questions every time, so that you can thoughtfully compare cases in class. Talk to Marjorie, she's great!
Do the case readings! It's not a demanding class, but worth really doing the reading so that you can actively engage with the course material.
I would recommend that everyone interested in development in the U.S. in any way take this course! It was GREAT!
